typeData.textContent:
This psychology course will introduce you to some of the major research areas within the field of psychology: the scientific study of behaviour.  The course begins with an overview of psychology and its research methods, and then covers several fundamental topics in psychology such as biological psychology, learning and memory, and conscious states.

This section of PSYC101 is a 3-credit online distance education course.  It has both synchronous (live; e.g., Q&A sessions, discussion sessions, and group activities) and asynchronous  components (not live; e.g., prerecorded lectures, online quizzes, and self-assessments).  Because it is a distance education course, most course-related activities are asynchronous.

The course uses an open-source text that is supplemented by many video-based lectures and online resources. In addition, the course contains interviews with some leading research psychologists and some educational animations.

There are no prerequisites or corequisites for this course.  Note that you cannot receive credit for both PSYC101 and PSYC100.

Crossword Citation: Crossword Labs. (n.d.). Free, Online Crossword Puzzle Maker. Retrieved from https://crosswordlabs.com/

nodes.title: Summary Information (Grace Logel)
nodes.description: This node contains a summary of all the information covered pertaining to the 4 lobes of the brain from the video and the crossword in the surrounding nodes.

typeData.textContent:
There are 4 lobes located within the brain...

1. Frontal Lobe: located in the front/anterior portion of the brain and involved in reasoning, motor control, emotion and language due to 3 regions found within the lobe
A. Motor Cortex involved in planning and coordinating movement
B. Prefrontal Lobe involved in higher-level cognition like judgement, reasoning and impulse
C. Broca’s Area involved in language production

2. Parietal Lobe: located posterior/behind the frontal lobe and involved in processing the body’s senses
A. Somatosensory cortex that is essential for processing sensory information across the body 
I. Topographical: a spatial relationship is maintained on the surface of the cortex

3. Temporal Lobe: located directly under/inferior to the parietal lobe and involved in hearing, memory, emotion and some aspects of language due to 2 regions found within the lobe
A. Auditory Cortex involved in processing auditory information
B. Wernicke’s Area involved in speech comprehension

4. Occipital Lobe: located directly in the back of the brain and involved in interpreting incoming visual information due to the primary visual cortex
A. Retinotopic: a close relationship between the position of an object in the visual field and the position represented on the cortex

nodes.title: Anatomy of the Eye: Fill in the Blanks (Jovinn Sidhu)
nodes.description: Fill in the missing words.

nodes.title: Trichromatic Theory and Colour Blindness (Eliza Berman)

typeData.textContent:
Colour blindness is a condition in which an individual does not perceive colour in the way other people due. First, to understand why some people are unable to see colour the same way others can, we need to review how colour vision works in the first place.

	Colour vision is a trait that many animals possess and it has a variety of uses, including object detection and object discrimination. In the human retina, there are rods and cones, which are receptors that work together in order for the brain to form an image. There are three different types of of cones, or photoreceptors, that detect colour: S cones, M cones, and L cones. The S cone detects  short wavelengths of  light, like the colour blue, M cones detect medium wavelengths, like the colour green, and L cones detect long wavelengths, like the colour red. These cone cells are located in the fovea, an area in the retina, and work best in bright conditions. We see more than just red, green and blue, which can be explained by the opponent colour theory, which is the theory that 3 mechanisms are responsible for the perception of colour, the opponency being between red and green, blue and yellow, and black and white. Then all visual visual information from the rods and cones are sent through the optic nerve in the back of the eye and is sent to the brain, which allows you to see shapes and colours.

	So why can’t some people see colour? Well, often times it is not that people cannot see colour at all, which is possible, but sometimes it is that people find it difficult to distinguish between certain colours. There are three major types of colour blindness: red-green colour blindness, blue-yellow colour blindness, and complete colour blindness. Red-green colour blindness results in the individual having difficulty distinguishing red and green, blue-yellow colour blindness means the person has trouble distinguishing between red from yellow and blue from green, and complete colour blindness means the person cannot see colour at all. Most commonly, colour blindness is caused by some or all of the cones missing in the retina, which is typically a condition that people are born with. The type of colourblindness is caused by the type of cones that are missing. The effects of colour blindness can also be made worse in lower lighting because cones work best in bright conditions. 






National Eye Institute. (2019). Types of Color Blindness. Retrieved from: https://www.nei.nih.gov/learn-about-eye-health/eye-conditions-and-diseases/color-blindness/types-color-blindness

Turbert, D. (2019). What Are he Symptoms and Causes of Color Blindness?. Retrieved from: https://www.aao.org/eye-health/diseases/color-blindness-symptoms

nodes.title: Parts of the Eye and Colour Blindness (Lindsay Anta)
Parts of the Eye and Colour Blindness (Lindsay Anta)
Colour Vision and Colour Blindness (Lindsay Anta)

nodes.title: Acetylcholine transmission, Memory and Disease(Chang Liu or Leo)

typeData.textContent:
Acetylcholine transmission and Memory and Disease
Posted byriot July 8, 2020 Leave a commenton Acetylcholine transmission and Memory and Disease
Acetylcholine (ACh) is a common type of neurotransmitter that exist in human bodies. Scientists found it plays crucial role in parts of both the peripheral and central nervous system of human brain. The level of Acetylcholine strongly determine a person’s capability of his or her memory function. Acetylcholine can helps to transmit singals and information from one neuron cell to other cells.

The Brain and Nervous System



Acetylcholine also acts at various places in the nervous system where it can serve as a neurotransmitter and also as a neuromodulator. It plays a role in motivation, arousal, attention, learning, and memory ACH is also involved in promoting REM sleep.

Disease and other damages

Several disease caused by the

Myasthenia Gravis: The disease myasthenia gravis, characterized by muscle weakness and fatigue, 

Alzheimer Disease: Critical cholinergic pathway deterioration in the CNS has been associated with the onset of Alzheimer’s disease.

Drugs and substances that interrupt acetylcholine function can have negative effects on the body and can even lead to death. Examples of such substances include some types of pesticides and nerve gasses.

Role of Acetylcholine in the aspect of Memory

Scientists believe that acetylcholine could control a repertoire of responses to novel information. 

Reference

Mysliveček, J. (1986). The role of acetylcholine and catecholamines in the memory processes in the newborn rat. (pp. 343-346) Elsevier Ltd. doi:10.1016/B978-0-08-034186-6.50064-5

Suryanarayanan, A. (2014). acetylcholine. (Third ed., pp. 49-50) Elsevier Inc. doi:10.1016/B978-0-12-386454-3.00218-9

Kropotov, J. D. (2016). Chapter 3.4 – memory systems. (pp. 231-242) Elsevier Inc. doi:10.1016/B978-0-12-410513-3.00014-0

Wenk, G. L. (2010). Your brain on food: How chemicals control your thoughts and feelings. New York;Oxford;: Oxford University Press.
